verse: Having assembled the materials and workers for the temple, Solomon began to build the Eternal’s temple on the second day in the second month of the fourth year of his reign. He built it in Jerusalem on Ornan the Jebusite’s threshing floor (which David had purchased and consecrated) on Mount Moriah (where Abraham had been willing to sacrifice Isaac to God generations before).
When Solomon prepared the plans of the True God’s temple, he modeled the design after temples in Syria and Canaan. The length was 90 feet and the width was 30 feet.
The length of the front porch was as wide as the temple (30 feet), and it was 30 feet high. The rooms of the temple were highly ornamented. The porch was gilded inside.
The main room was paneled with gilded cypress wood and engraved with palm trees and ornamental chains.
The entire temple was decorated with precious stones and gilded with gold from Parvaim.

Even the supports and fasteners were gilded—the beams, the thresholds, the walls, the doors, and the nails (which weighed 20 ounces each). The walls were engraved with winged guardians, and the upper rooms were gilded.
Inside the most holy place were two gilded, sculpted winged creatures,
each with a wingspan of 15 feet.
Together, their wings spanned across the room guarding the most holy place facing the main room and standing upright on their feet.
A veil of violet, purple, and crimson fabrics and fine linen, embroidered with winged creatures, covered the entrance to the most holy place.

Before the porch stood two columns, 52 feet high, crowned with 90-inch-high capitals. Solomon made decorative chains in the most holy place, adorned them with 100 pomegranates, and draped them on the tops of the columns. The column on the right was named Jachin, meaning “He establishes,” and the column on the left was named Boaz, meaning “He strengthens.”
